Package fr.spacefox.jrational

Class Rational

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.lang.Number
      • fr.spacefox.jrational.Rational
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Comparable<Rational>
    public final class Rational
extends java.lang.Number
implements java.lang.Comparable<Rational>
    Immutable rational numbers. Quotient p/q of two integers, a numerator p and a non-zero denominator q.

    Internal representation uses two BigInteger for numerator and denominator. This has the following implications:

    1. Precision: Rational’s precision depends on BigInteger precision, which is arbitrary and virtually infinite.
    2. Performances: Rational’s performance highly depends on BigInteger performances, as most operation are backed by computations on BigInteger.

    Semantics of arithmetics operation and public API method names also follows BigInteger ones. Also, an ArithmeticException is thrown when a builder or a method would attempt an illegal operation.

    Constructors and builders: There is no public constructor for Rational. The only way to create a Rational is to use a static builder Rational.of(something).

    Limitations: There is only one zero (no positive or negative zero), and special values like infinities and "not a number" cannot be represented with a Rational.

    Precision and performances: As performances directly depends on underlying BigInteger arithmetics. This implies the more "precise" the Rational is, slower it is. Preliminary tests seems the computing complexity is in O(n), with n the size of numerator and denominator. This is important as chained calculus may lead to an irreducible rational which still is a quotient of two very large integers (thousands of decimal figures) then slow to handle, even if the rational number itself isn’t very large or small. The method magnitude() method will help to detect Rational backed with large BigInteger; and the approximate() and canonicalForm() methods allows to shrink them to more reasonable numbers.

    Approximate rationals: A Rational may be approximate (see isApproximate() method). This denotes this rational is only an approximation of the real value. The real value may be, or not, an irrational number in the mathematical definition. There is no constructor nor builder to create an approximate Rational, as all the builder require exact values. There are three ways to get an approximate Rational. First is provided constants. Second is to call approximate() on an existing number, the result will be flagged as approximate if and only if an approximation has been done. The second one is through arithmetic methods that can lead to irrational results. Any operation that implies an approximate Rational will always have an approximate as result.

    See Also:
    BigInteger, SortedMap, SortedSet, Serialized Form
    API Note:
    This class has a natural ordering that is inconsistent with equals. Care should be exercised if Rational objects are used as keys in a SortedMap or elements in a SortedSet since Rational’s natural ordering is inconsistant with equals. See Comparable, SortedSet or SortedMap for more information.

    • Method Detail

      • canonicalForm

        @NotNull
public @NotNull Rational canonicalForm()
        Returns the canonical form of this Rational.

        The canonical form is an unique way to represent this Rational as an irreductible fraction a/b where a and b are coprime integers and b > 0.

        Performance notice: This operation implies to compute the GCD of a and b, which may be long for high magnitudes. The higher is the magnitude, the longest is this computation. This may be an issue with very high magnitude Rationals, as the one produced by calculus chains or loops. Consider to force canonical form earlier in the process, or to use approximations.

        Returns:
        the canonical form of this Rational, or this if this is alread the canonical form.
        See Also:
        magnitude(), approximate(), BigInteger.gcd(BigInteger)

      • of

        @NotNull
public static @NotNull Rational of​(@NotNull
                                   @NotNull java.math.BigInteger numerator,
                                   @NotNull
                                   @NotNull java.math.BigInteger denominator)
        Builds a rational number from two non-null BigInteger values.
        Parameters:
        numerator - the fraction’s numerator.
        denominator - the fraction’s denominator.
        Returns:
        the rational number expressed as the quotient of numerator / denominator, normalized: fraction has been reduced if possible (real representation is irreducible), and sign worn by numerator (real denominator is > 0).
        Throws:
        java.lang.ArithmeticException - if denominator is zero.

      • of

        @NotNull
public static @NotNull Rational of​(@NotNull
                                   @NotNull java.math.BigDecimal decimal)
        Builds a rational number from a BigDecimal value.

        The returned value will be exact but the "scale" notion of BigDecimal will be lost.

        With provided decimal, the rational will be built as decimal.unscaledValue() / 10^(decimal.scale()) Then normalized as every rational build. This implies lost of "scale" notion, and the resulting denominator may not be a power of 10.

        Examples:

        • Rational.of(new BigDecimal("1.23") gives 123/100
        • Rational.of(new BigDecimal("0.700") gives 7/10 (as well as Rational.of(new BigDecimal("0.70000"))
        • Rational.of(new BigDecimal("1.50") gives 3/2 (and not 15/10 which is reducible)
        Parameters:
        decimal - the value to express as a rational.
        Returns:
        the value as rational number, normalized: fraction has been reduced if possible (real representation is irreducible), and sign worn by numerator (real denominator is > 0).

      • of

        @NotNull
public static @NotNull Rational of​(@NotNull
                                   @NotNull java.lang.String s)
        Shortcut for of(new BigDecimal(s))
        Parameters:
        s - the decimal value as String in base 10
        Returns:
        the value as rational number, normalized: fraction has been reduced if possible (real representation is irreducible), and sign worn by numerator (real denominator is > 0).

      • of

        @NotNull
public static @NotNull Rational of​(@NotNull
                                   @NotNull java.lang.String numerator,
                                   @NotNull
                                   @NotNull java.lang.String denominator)
        Shortcut for of(new BigInteger(numerator), new BigInteger(denominator))
        Parameters:
        numerator - the numerator value as String in base 10
        denominator - the denominator value as String in base 10
        Returns:
        the rational number expressed as the quotient of numerator / denominator, normalized: fraction has been reduced if possible (real representation is irreducible), and sign worn by numerator (real denominator is > 0).
        Throws:
        java.lang.ArithmeticException - if denominator is zero.

      • of

        @NotNull
public static @NotNull Rational of​(double d)
        This builder is provided to simplify some kind of interfaces and should not be used only unless you know exactly what you are doing!

        This builder will convert the exact real value from the floating, including all approximations inherent to the IEEE-754 norm. This implies many values with a simple decimal expression that can’t have an exact floating representation, including numbers as common as 0.1.

        Examples:

        • Rational.of(0.1d) gives 3602879701896397/36028797018963968, which is the exact irreducible value of 0.1 expressed as double in Java.
        • Rational.of(0.1f) gives 13421773/134217728, which is the exact irreducible value of 0.1 expressed as float in Java.

        Technically, this method checks if the double is a real finite number, and returns Rational.of(new BigDecimal(number).

        Parameters:
        d - the value to express as a rational.
        Returns:
        the Rational expressed by the provided double.
        Throws:
        java.lang.ArithmeticException - if the provided double is not a number or infinite.
        See Also:
        for details of number conversion.

      • compareTo

        public int compareTo​(@NotNull
                     @NotNull Rational val)
        Compares this Rational with the specified Rational. Two Rational objects that are equals in value but have different pairs of numerators and denominators (example: 2/4 and 3/6) are equals. The approximate flag is ignored, so an approximate Rational will be considered equal to any other Rational which is equal in value, despite this other Rational is approximate or not. This is different from the equals(Object) behaviour.
        Specified by:
        compareTo in interface java.lang.Comparable<Rational>
        Parameters:
        val - Rational to which this Rational is to be compared.
        Returns:
        -1, 0 or 1 as this Rational is numerically less than, equal to, or greater than val.

      • equals

        public boolean equals​(java.lang.Object o)
        Compares this Rational with the specified Object for equality.

        Unlike compareTo(Rational), an approximate Rational is never equals to another Rational, except himself (the same object).

        Overrides:
        equals in class java.lang.Object
        Parameters:
        o - Object to which this Rational is to be compared.
        Returns:
        true if and only if the specified Object is a Rational who is not approximate.

      • bigIntegerValue

        @NotNull
public @NotNull java.math.BigInteger bigIntegerValue()
        Returns the value of the specified number as a BigInteger.
        Returns:
        the numeric value represented by this object after conversion to type BigInteger
        Implementation Note:
        This is a "fast" implementation that returns numerator // denominator where // is the integer division. For a more precise conversion, call approximate(1) before.

      • bigDecimalValue

        @NotNull
public @NotNull java.math.BigDecimal bigDecimalValue()
        Returns the value of the specified number as a BigDecimal.
        Returns:
        the numeric value represented by this object after conversion to type BigInteger
        Implementation Note:
        The output BigDecimal has an enormous scale of 1074, which is required to avoid precision lost on further convertion to double on worst cases.

      • magnitude

        public int magnitude()
        Returns the number of bits in the minimal representation of this Rational, excluding a sign bit. (Computes (ceil(log2(numerator < 0 ? -numerator : numerator+1)) + ceil(log2(denominator + 1), as denominator is always > 1).

        This is useful to detect potential performance issues.

        The implementation uses BigInteger#bitLength() on both numerator and denominator. This leads to some strange boundary behaviours, as (0).bitLength() = 0, (1).bitLength() = 1 but (-1).bitLength() = 0. This is not a problem as this methods returns the magnitude of the Rational and not an exact metric.

        Returns:
        the number of bits in the minimal representation of this Rational, excluding a sign bit.
        See Also:
        BigInteger.bitLength()

      • approximate

        @NotNull
public @NotNull Rational approximate()
        Returns an approximation of this Rational with the denominator is <= 2^128. Return this if the condition is already matched. If an approximation is done, the returned rational is flagged as approximate.

        This is useful on long chains of calculus that leads to unreasonable long numerators and denominators and canonical forms doesn’t help.

        Returns:
        an approximation of this Rational with the denominator is <= 2^128.

      • approximate

        @NotNull
public @NotNull Rational approximate​(long denominatorMax)
        Returns an approximation of this Rational with the denominator is <= denominatorMax. Return this if the condition is already matched. If an approximation is done, the returned rational is flagged as approximate.

        This is useful on long chains of calculus that leads to unreasonable long numerators and denominators and canonical forms doesn’t help.

        Parameters:
        denominatorMax - The maximum value for the denominator, included.
        Returns:
        an approximation of this Rational with the denominator is <= denominatorMax.

      • approximate

        @NotNull
public @NotNull Rational approximate​(@NotNull
                                     @NotNull java.math.BigInteger denominatorMax)
        Returns an approximation of this Rational with the denominator is <= denominatorMax. Return this if the condition is already matched. If an approximation is done, the returned rational is flagged as approximate.

        This is useful on long chains of calculus that leads to unreasonable long numerators and denominators and canonical forms doesn’t help.

        Parameters:
        denominatorMax - The maximum value for the denominator, included.
        Returns:
        an approximation of this Rational with the denominator is <= denominatorMax.
        Throws:
        java.lang.ArithmeticException - if the denominatorMax is negative or zero.
        Implementation Note:
        current implementation will return this if current denominator is smaller or equal than, and an approximation of current Rational whose denominator is exactly the one in parameter elsewhere. The result may not be a canonical form.
